QUALITY
High & Mediums Growns showed a marginal improvement, whilst the Low Growns were similar to last.
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 2
Page 2
COMMENTS
Auction offerings totalled 6.4 M/Kgs, marginally lower to the 6.5 M/Kgs on offer the previous week. Following the Iran-Israel ceasefire, a greater degree of stability was witnessed in the market and an upward trend in prices all round.
Ex-Estate offerings totalled 0.83 M/Kgs and here again, marginally lower to the 0.86 M/Kgs on offer the previous week. Overall quality of teas on offer were slightly preferable to last.
Improved demand, particularly for the better Westerns, which appreciated by Rs. 50-100 per kg and more. Prices at the lower end of the market for the BOP's were weak and were firm to Rs. 50 per kg easier in most instances. Corresponding BOPF's often appreciated by a similar margin widening the price parity at the lower end between BOP/BOPF's greatly in favour of the latter. Nuwara Eliya BOP/BOPF's were mostly unsold in the backdrop of weak quality. Uda Pussellawas' were firm and easier, whilst the Uva BOP/BOPF's were firm and dearer and here again, particularly for BOPF grade.
CTC teas - BP1's had hardly any offerings. PF1's - High & Mid Growns were firm and up to Rs. 50 per kg dearer for the better teas, whilst the Low Growns continued to sell well at firm to marginally dearer rates.
It was heartening to witness the better teas realising substantial price gains vis-à-vis their poorer counterparts and a significant price parity between the two would certainly be of encouragement to producers of good quality teas.
Selective buying on account of shippers to the UK and the continent. Shippers to Japan, China and South Africa were reasonably active, whilst shippers to the CIS and the Middle East lent good support.
From a global perspective, there appears to be a dearth of good quality teas vis-à-vis the plainer/poorer counterparts and in these circumstances with overall volumes showing a decline, tea prices are likely to remain buoyant in the forthcoming sales.
Low Growns totalled approximately 2.5 M/Kgs. All categories met with good demand.
In the Leafy and Semi-Leafy catalogues, Select Best and Best BOP1's were firm to dearer, whilst the balance together with the bolder varieties sold around last levels. Well-made OP1's appreciated, whilst the balance eased. Well-made OP's together with cleaner Below Best and shorter varieties were dearer. However, the balance together with the mixed/open varieties were irregular. Well-made OPA's were dearer, whilst the balance maintained at last levels.  Select Best and Best PEK's were firm to dearer, whilst the balance together with the mixed/open varieties were easier. Teas at the bottom sold around last levels. Well-made PEK1's appreciated, whilst the balance sold around last levels.
In the Tippy catalogue, well-made FBOP's together with the cleaner Below Best and cleaner teas at the bottom appreciated, whilst the balance were firm on last. Select Best FF1's were firm, whilst the Best and Below Best varieties together with cleaner teas at the bottom were dearer. The balance sold around last levels.
In the Premium catalogue, Very Tippy teas together with the Best and Below Best varieties met with good demand and were dearer, whilst the balance too appreciated to a lesser extent.
NOTE
Next week's Auction (Sale No. 26) is scheduled for Monday, 7 July and Tuesday, 8 July 2025
NATIONAL TEA SALE AVERAGES - JUNE 2025
Key Highlights:
*
Total Elevation Average declined by Rs. 48.05 in comparison to the previous month
*
Cumulative variance recorded a negative Rs. 107.13 and USD 0.23 against January-June 2024
* All elevations recorded negative variances both in LKR and USD terms month on month and cumulatively
NOTE: The USD values are provisional
* National tea sales average for the month of June 2025 recorded Rs. 1,103.27 (USD 3.68), recording a decline of Rs. 48.05 (USD 0.17) in comparison with the May 2025 average of Rs. 1,151.32 (USD 3.85).
* In comparison to the June 2024 average of Rs. 1,243.69 (USD 4.09), shows a decline of Rs. 140.42 (USD 0.41) YOY.
* Total National Sale Average for the year 2025 (to-date) was recorded at Rs. 1,158.54 (USD 3.89), a decline of Rs. 107.13 (USD 0.23) against the corresponding year's average of Rs. 1,265.67 (USD 4.12).
Elevation-Wise Analysis - June 2025:
* High Grown average in June 2025 recorded a decrease of Rs. 41.79 and USD 0.15 month on month, whilst a decline of Rs. 136.15 and USD 0.41 was witnessed vis-à-vis June 2024.
* Medium Grown average in June 2025 recorded a negative variance of Rs. 37.70 and USD 0.13 month on month, whilst a decline of Rs. 100.69 and USD 0.29 was witnessed vis-à-vis June 2024.
* Low Grown average in June 2025 recorded a decrease of Rs. 53.31 and USD 0.18
month on month, whilst showing a decrease
of Rs. 149.46 and USD 0.44 vis-à-vis June 2024.
* All regions recorded negative variances during the period January-June 2025 in comparison to the cumulative corresponding period of 2024 both in LKR and USD terms.
(Refer statistical details on Page No. 9)
World Tea News
FORBES & WALKER TEA BROKERS (PVT) LTD SALE OF - 01ST/ 02ND JULY 2025
Forbes and Walker Tea Brokers
MOST COMPREHENSIVE WEBSITE ON TEA
www.forbestea.com
Page 3
Page 3
MARKET
A selection of better teas appreciated further, whilst the others were irregular
HIGH GROWN TEAS
BOP
Western's in the Best and Below Best categories - A selection of teas gained by Rs. 100-200 per kg following special inquiry, whilst the others were irregular. Teas at the lower end of the market declined by up to Rs. 50 per kg. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's were Rs. 20-40 per kg easier, whilst the Uva's were firm and dearer by a similar margin.
BOPF
Western's in the Best and Below Best categories gained by Rs. 50-100 per kg and substantially more for select invoices following quality/special inquiry, whilst the others were firm and dearer to a lesser extent. At the lower end of the market, select coloury teas appreciated by up to Rs. 50 per kg, whilst the others were irregular. Nuwara Eliya's were mostly unsold. Uda Pussellawa's declined by Rs. 20-40 per kg. Uva's - Select high-priced teas of last week were generally firm, whilst the other clean leaf coloury sorts gained by up to Rs. 100 per kg.
OP/OPA
Well-made varieties were firm, whilst the others and poorer sorts were dearer by Rs. 20 per kg.
PEKOE/PEKOE1
Flavoury PEK's declined by Rs. 40-60 per kg and were mostly unsold, whilst the Orthodox Leafy PEK's gained by Rs. 40 per kg. Best PEK1's appreciated by Rs. 40-60 per kg. Best Rotovane PEK's sold at last levels, whilst the others declined and were mostly unsold.
FBOP/FBOPF1
Select Best flavoury FBOP's declined by Rs. 60-80 per kg and were mostly unsold. Better Orthodox FBOP's appreciated by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the FBOPF1's gained by Rs. 40-60 per kg. Below Best FBOP/FBOPF1's appreciated by Rs. 40 per kg, whilst the teas at the lower end were dearer by Rs. 40-60 per kg.

OFF GRADES
FGS1/FGS
Teas in the Best category which commenced firm on last levels, declined towards the latter part of the sale. Below Best varieties were firm to dearer following quality. Teas at the lower end of the market maintained. Low Grown - Clean leaf varieties together with the Below Best varieties were firm to dearer, whilst the teas at the bottom end of the market declined sharply. CTC - Which commenced firm, declined as the sale progressed.
BROKENS
In general, were firm.
BOP1A
Main Grade reducer varieties in the Best category were firm, whilst the balance were easier by Rs. 20 per kg and declined further towards the latter part of the sale. Below Best varieties  which commenced easier by Rs. 10-20 per kg, continued to decline as the sale progressed, whilst the  poorer sorts maintained.

BOP's, in general, were firm.
BOP1

OP1

OP

OPA

PEKOE

BOPF
BOPF's, in general, were firm on last.
FBOPF/FBOPF1
Very Tippy teas together with the Best and Below Best varieties met with good demand and were dearer, whilst the balance too appreciated to a lesser extent. Select Best FF1's were firm, whilst the Best and Below Best varieties together with cleaner teas at the bottom were dearer. The balance were firm on last.

CROP AND WEATHER
For the period 25 June - 01 July 2025
Western/Nuwara Eliya Regions
The Western Region reported rain, whilst the Nuwara Eliya Region reported bright weather throughout the week. The Department of Meteorology expects showers in both regions in the week ahead.
Uva/Uda Pussellawa Regions
Bright weather was reported from the Uva and Uda Pussellawa regions throughout the week. According to the Department of Meteorology, showers are expected in both regions in the week ahead.
Low Growns
The Low Grown Region reported bright mornings and occasional evening showers throughout the week. Fairly strong winds are expected in the Low Grown Region in the week ahead according to the Department of Meteorology.
Crop Intake
The Nuwara Eliya Region maintained the crop intake, whilst the Western, Uva, Uda Pussellawa and Low Grown regions reported a decrease.

MOMBASA AUCTION
SALE OF - 30TH JUNE AND 01ST JULY 2025 (SALE NO. 26)
MARKETS
Pakistan Packers and Bazaar were active with maintained interest from Yemen and other Middle Eastern countries. Kazakhstan and other CIS states lent strong support with some enquiry from Afghanistan.   Egyptian Packers maintained activity with UK selective. Russia improved absorption but at lower rates with  Sudan absent; South Sudan remained quiet. There was some activity from Local Packers with Somalia active at the lower end of the market.
OFFERINGS
Leaf Grades                  -    106,918 packages (6,996,177.00 kilos) - 55.00% unsold.
Dust Grades                -      74,140 packages (5,532,180.00 kilos) - 41.49% unsold.
Secondary Grades       -      20,580 packages (1,081,609.00 kilos) - 21.28% unsold.
LEAF GRADES (M2 & M3)
BP1:
Best - Appreciated by up to USC36 with some teas substantially dearer by USC56, USC85 and USC90.
Brighter - Irregular ranging between firm to mostly dearer by up to USC10 to easier by a similar margin.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were steady to USC10 above last levels where sold while plantation mediums were irregular.
Lower Medium - Firm to USC4 dearer to easier by up to USC11.
Plainer - Shed by up to USC13.
PF1:
Best - Met irregular interest varying between steady to USC15 dearer to easier by a similar margin.
Brighter - Saw irregular enquiry and varied between firm to USC10 above last levels to easier by up to USC20.
Mediums - KTDA mediums were steady to USC15 dearer to easier by up to USC4 with plantation mediums up to USC15 above previous levels but some lines shed up to USC9.
Lower Medium - Irregular varying between firm to mostly dearer by up to USC10 but select lines were up to USC3 below previous levels.
Plainer - Were irregular and varied between USC3 above last levels to easier by up to USC6.

BANGLADESH AUCTION
SALE OF - 30TH  JUNE 2025 (SALE NO. 08)
CTC LEAF: 46,797 packages of teas on offer met with a good demand.
BROKENS/FANNINGS: A fair weight of good liquoring varieties sold well but mostly at easier rates ranging between Tk.255/- and Tk.280/-. Medium varieties met with a little less demand and sold between Tk.248/- and Tk. 253/-. Lesser varieties met with some demand but there were many withdrawals and where sold fetched between Tk.245/- and Tk.247/-. BLF teas met with a fairly good demand with a fair weight being unsold and these realised prices between Tk.170/- and Tk.219/-.
DUST: 12,686 packages of teas on offer met with a good demand. Well made good liquoring Dusts were in good demand and sold well in line with quality. Others were an
easier market and sold at a drop of Tk.5/- to Tk.8/- closely following quality. BLF Dusts met with a good competition with only a few withdrawals. Blenders lent strong support with fair interest from the Loose tea buyers.
COMMENTS: There was less competition noticeable in this sale particularly from the Blenders. Loose tea buyers were also not as active and as a result, withdrawals were quite heavy.
Dusts sold well.
Our Catalogue: (Sale 8) Avg : Tk 240.52, Sold 73.66 % , (Sale 7) Avg : Tk 252.12, Sold 82.64%

JAKARTA AUCTION
SALE OF - 27TH JUNE 2025 (SALE NO. 26)
CTC LEAF
The total CTC leaf teas sold this week was 66.30%(1,278,830.61kgs) of the total offering of 1,928,748.15Kgs Demand:- Good for the Best, good & better medium, subdued for the medium and plainer.
Market:- Good demand prevailed for the best & good category teas with prices at irregular levels based on quality. Few invoices of better medium category fetched handsome gains on competition. Medium and plainer teas continue to see a decline in prices with few blacker fanning grade selling at steady prices.
Buying Pattern:- Major blenders were fairly active on better category, medium & plainer broken. Lesser participation from the western India Packateer was seen this week. Regional & other up country buyers were active on best & good teas but restricted their buying on medium and plainer teas. Exporters to Iraq, CIS and Russia continued lend fair support. The major blenders off- take was 49.00% of the total CTC leaf sold.
ORTHODOX LEAF
Demand:- Good and slightly improved for leaf grade, good demand on the dust.
Market:- The whole leaf in both High grown and others sold irregular and dearer following quality. A similar trend continued for the broken too. Fanning grade sold irregularly easier.
Buying Pattern:- Russian and CIS buyers continued to be fairly active along with Internal buyers.
CTC DUST
DEMAND: - Good demand for the best, good and better medium, remainders met with selective demand..
MARKET: - CTC dust offer this week was at 495,613.34Kgs of which 358,268.54kgs were sold (72.29%).
Best & good teas sold at irregular prices closely following quality and competition. Better medium teas sold irregualr and dearer especially at the top end. Medium and plainer dust sold irregularly easier by Rs 2 to 4 with larger percentage of teas in this segments continued to remain unsold due to want of bids.
BUYING PATTERN: - Major blenders continued to be selective. Regional and local packeteers were fairly selective. Up country buyers were subdued. Increased participation from the exporters were seen this week but at easier prices on the medium and plainer teas and they restricted their purchases to blacker sorts only.
ORTHODOX DUST
DEMAND: - Good demand on primary dust, secondary met with less demand.
MARKET: - Primary dust sold dearer on quality and competition & secondary teas sold irregular and easier.
BUYING PATTERN: -Regional & local packateers were fairly active on primary dusts. Exporters were selective on the secondary dusts.
Courtesy -  J.Thomas & Co. Pvt. Ltd.
